text:
ApplicationContext cannot find resources (such as web.xml) if they do not have 
a "long" filename in lower case. In that case it considers the filename to be 
uppercase, and the resource is considered missing.

This is critical on Win9x/Me platforms as the file system is not case-
sensitive, and standard file copy routines often omit "long" names if they fit 
the "8.3" pattern.

This is critical if you need to distribute a preconfigured Tomcat system to 
different computers with different OS's.

How-to-reproduce:
1. Have a multiple-boot system with Windows 98 on FAT drive and Windows 2000 on 
NTFS.
2. Boot as Windows 2000 and install Tomcat 4.0.1.
3. Execute xcopy *.* /s/e on Tomcat directory to the FAT drive.
4. Boot as Windows 98 and launch Tomcat.
5. Start a browser and load the Tomcat start page. The start page loads, but 
most applications are not available.
6. Have a look at log files. There will be multiple complaints on 
missing "web.xml" files.

text:
This is normal bahaviour, since tomcat (and java..) is fully case sensitive. 
You have to find another way to copy your files over, so the case is not 
altered. Since I don't run win9x, I don't know an alternative for this (maybe 
deploying by default on the FAT file system is option?)

creator: remm@apache.org
text:
Yes, we implemented a few mechanisms which will enforce a Unix-like case-
sensitivity when Tomcat is run under Windows. On one hand, it may be annoying, 
but it does make your webapps portable on non-Windows OSes.
Here, it looks like the problem is a side-effect of this, and I can't see any 
workaround.
